The EU has gone too far in gazumping its member states’ power to domestically legislate. IMO, the EC should be all about a Free Trade zone and not about a comprehensive EU Zone Government. (This is basically the reason for Brexit)
For example, I wrote to the Taoiseach regarding the inequity of an Irish citizen being denied car insurance because she had an Australian Driving Licence and after 6
months of passing the buck from one department to another, I was informed that
the relevant Minister could not do anything about this blatant inequity due to EU regulations.
A simple thing like a citizen’s eligibility for car insurance and, consequently, her ability to drive her car in Ireland should not be regulated by the EC, IMO.
It seems silly for a Bulgarian or a Rumanian who has driven on the right side of the road, can’t speak English let alone Irish to be eligible for Irish car Insurance when an Irish citizen , born, educated and lived in Ireland
for 21 years (but now living in Australia) and who has driven on the left side of the road all her life is denied Irish Car Insurance and thereby prevented from driving her own car while visiting Ireland.
What has Ireland come to?
Do we need to be refugees to get a fair go?

@Steven Fitzpatrick: The British (or Kate Howie, at any rate) seem to think that the Irish government is going to pay for it and they (she) could be right. A lot depends on how the future, post-Brexit UK shapes up. The Good Friday Agreement (GFA) was predicated on the understanding that Britain no longer had any “selfish or strategic interest in Ireland”. Since Brexit, the language has changed and some are openly calling into question the value of the GFA. The truth is that, in the context of Brexit (both the negotiations in the run up and what follows after), Northern Ireland becomes a valuable strategic asset, from Britain’s point of view. To some, it might seem like Britain’s legacy problem but post-Brexit, it could be a torn in the EU’s side – one that Britain would use for maximum leverage in the event that the EU doesn’t ‘play nice’. If things get nasty, Britain will know how to use the existence of an invisible and largely porous border to their advantage. How is the EU going to face up to the problem of sealing it, if that is deemed to be necessary? Get the Irish Government to do it? That would be controversial but not unfathomable. How did the border come into being in the first place and how has it lasted this long? People harbouring the dream that Brexit is a further stepping stone in the inexorable drive towards a United Ireland, might do well to prepare themselves for a (crushing) disappointment. Who is to say that the outcome might not be to make partition, not just formal but as final and complete as say, that of India and Pakistan?

The Princess Trilogy By Jean Sasson
Draft review
When a girl is born in Saudi Arabia, her birth is not legally recorded. It is an event of insignificance.
‘The Princess Trilogy’ tells the story of one such princess, Sultana, her eight sisters, her brother, husband and two daughters. It is rare to get such a realistic, frightening and honest hands on insight in to the life of the royal princesses born in to the exuberant wealth of Saudi Arabia.
She gives us a glimpse in to a guarded and secret society. She describes in detail the experiences that she, her sisters, daughters and friends endured at the hands a strict, male dominated society, steeped in archaic cruelty, egotism, ignorance, abuse and violence.
She tells us about one of her friends who innocently flirted with a young boy. Her punishment was death by drowning. The young girl was murdered in the family swimming pool. The event was attended by the girl’s family, friends and neighbors. Sultana was forced by her father to watch her friend die.
Another friend narrowly escaped death for a mediocre oversight. The young woman spent the rest of her life under stringent house arrest in what is commonly known as ‘The Women’s Room’. She spent the remainder of her life there, alone with no human contact, nothing for company except the voices in her head that would eventually drive her to madness and death
Her brother Alex is guilty of brutal barbarities, including the rape of an eight year old child. On another occasion as the result of a’ sexual emergency’, he raped a woman in a coma in her hospital bed.
When a woman dies in Saudi Arabia, her death is not legally recorded. It is an event of insignificance.

Britain has an obligation to implement international law and process asylum applicants who arrive from countries where they might be persecuted if returned to. However, under the Dublin Agreement (an international treaty registered with the UN), the UK has no obligation to accept asylum seekers coming from a safe country like France where the asylum seeker had opportunity and obligation to make their asylum claim.

@Peter O’Muiri: True… However with the influx of high numbers and the fact that the real identity of the applicant is not disclosed in arrival, any asylum application made, is accepted and processed. By the time the real identity is verified via interview or fingerprints, the applicant is in the country many months. The applicant can then appeal the decision and drag the case through the courts system. If the applicant in the meantime manages to secure a marriage to an EU national, he or she can then apply to stay on the basis of EU treaty rights. Following this they can then make application for their family to join them. If the EU marriage is fake, they can also later apply for a divorce and then apply for the real wife to join them also.

In many ways the border is just being used as a proxy by all 3 parties:
- The border is a proxy for the ROI maintaining a close and frictionless trading relationship with the mainland UK. The real economic goal is the common travel area and business as usual for Irish exporters to the UK. Our government knows that the Irish sea would never be accepted as a border, so the real goal is to forces a soft brexit
- The EUs interests in obtaining a soft brexit deal and keeping the UK within its customs and other controls are well served by the border question. They can maintain a peace stance, a comradery with their Irish partners stance, but the border solution will be a reflection of the trade solutions for Rotterdam, Le Havre, Calais etc.
- The border is a proxy both sides in the UK, for soft brexiteers and remainers to push for remaining within the envelope of extra-EU co-operation; for hard brexiteers as a symbolic shutting of the border with the EU, and as a symbol of the UK’s autonomy and self-governance.
I feel sorry for the residents of the North, in both communities, continuing to be used as a proxy by all sides, all of whom are protesting that their peace and economic security is of the highest priority, but whom are in reality mostly using them as a political football for a complex future trade deal.

@Paul Smith: Like Cal below states perhaps your proof could be more compelling, such as maybe this article from Christine Kinealy https://www.historyireland.com/18th-19th-century-history/food-exports-from-ireland-1846-47/
In case you don’t want to read it all I’ll quote you a section, (excuse the length but there were a lot of exports)
The export of livestock to Britain (with the exception of pigs) also increased during the Famine. Whilst the export of pigs decreased, the export of bacon and ham increased from 930 cwt. in 1846 to 1,061 cwt. in 1847. In total over three million live animals were exported between 1846-50, more than the number of people who emigrated during the Famine years. In 1847, 9,992 calves were exported from Ireland to Britain, which represented a thirty-three per cent increase on exports on the previous year.
A wide variety of other foodstuffs left Ireland apart from livestock—vegetables and pulses (particularly peas, beans and onions), dairy products, fish (especially salmon, oysters and herrings) and even rabbits. In February 1847, 377 boxes of ‘fish and eggs’ and 383 boxes of fish were imported into Bristol alone. The butter export trade was particularly buoyant. In the first week of 1847, for example, 4,455 firkins of butter (a firkin equals nine gallons) were exported from Ireland to Liverpool. In the following week, this had risen to 4,691 firkins. Large quantities of butter were exported from Cork to all parts of Britain. For example, in the first nine months of 1847, 56,557 firkins of butter were exported to Bristol and 34,852 firkins to Liverpool. During the same period, 3,435 poultry were exported to Liverpool and 2,375 to Bristol.

The loss to the EU in a hard Brexit scenario is minimal compared to the loss the EU will face if the UK gets a good deal and prospers outside the EU. Similar to the Greek situation, the EU must inflict the hardest cost possible on the UK in this instance.
However, the EU took a lot of criticism in their approach to the Greek crisis. They did not come across as a friendly and cooperative bloc. This is where Ireland and the Irish border comes in. The Irish border allows the EU to inflict a substantial cost on the UK for leaving. And it can all be completed by actually appearing to be supportive of smaller EU states.
The UK won’t accept the restrictions that the EU will aim to put on them in the talks. So both the EU and UK will figure that a “no deal” is the best outcome for both parties. Leo and Simon will rejoice that their EU friends have stuck beside them without realising that a “no deal” is actually the worst outcome for Ireland.

The truth about globalism from Brexiteers eventually come true. No matter how much one hates it (immigrants, big trading blocks making the rules) it is the world we live in today and that world is about getting access to hundreds of millions of the world’s wealthiest populace. Britain outside the EU loses access to the EU’s marketplace and the EU’s FTA trade deals to sixty-one countries outside the EU. Getting a free-trade deal on goods is easy, its almost impossible when it comes to service, capital, and supply chains. There are three big marketplaces on the planet, namely EU, ASEAN, and USA. All three are highly protective and use their size as leverage to get trade deals that suit them. ASEAN or USA would be more than happy to sign Britain up to an FTA deal on goods and send a super-sized container ship to Britain’s shores, but that is missing the point completely of being a member of a trading block and it can have detrimental effects like a large quota of NZ / Australian lamb putting Welsh farmers out of business. Hence trade deals take years to accomplish in order to set tariffs correctly and get a trade deal that is suitable for Britain. The Brexiteers are liars, who know full well that Britain will never leave the EU as Westminster will never allow it, they are doing it for their own selfish political gain or have ulterior motives that are not transparent. Leaving the EU for a special trade deal with USA will not be a good idea, for starters American industry will colonise the UK and USA is too far away for Britain to access American supply chains. Ships take a long time as opposed to road, rail, sea, and air transportation links with EU and the fact Europe is on Britain’s doorstep.

An entertaining piece. The comparisons are flimsy and superficial, but it’s the sort of take I enjoy debating over a beer.
The comparisons made are:
1. Both issues stemmed from plebiscites: But so what? Democracy was a generally accepted idea in these islands at both times.
2. The negotiations took place against an unequal political landscape: So what? Life is often unequal.
3. One side had to pay the other to leave: Wrong and disingenuous – The UK is not being asked to pay a portion of an invading empire’s debt, they are being asked to fund previous commitments on projects and UK officials’ pensions. Furthermore – they can simply refuse to pay. It’s their own prerogative.
4. Sovereignty. This is funny – the UK is not being forced to handover any sovereignty whatsoever. They can leave without a backstop if they choose. Furthermore, the customs and standards arrangements in the backstop are not onerous. Even from a practical perspective, there are currently livestock checks between the two islands, and every passenger already has to show a passport flying from Belfast to, say, Birmingham. The argument that NI would have to take on future EU standards is a bit weak – NI farmers want to sell into the EU and know dropping standards will not be good for business.
I like a good debate though, and I suppose it is interesting to discuss…

May’s position has only one likely conclusion – a ‘no-deal’ Brexit. This will be a disaster for Britain and a catastrophe for Ireland. In politically normal times we could perhaps depend on the opposition in Westminster to provide an alternative, but sadly, the Labour Party is immersed in a concocted “anti-semitism” controversy, while the far-left faction currently in control of Labour are at one with their mirror-image counterparts on the right of the Tory party in wanting to be rid of the shackles of EU membership. The irony is that the far-right wants Brexit because it will allow them to follow a regulation-free course of ultra capitalism, while the far-left believes the EU shackles the UK to capitalism, and precludes nationalising the commanding heights of the economy they desire. Given the far greater likelihood of the Tories continuing to be the principal governing party unless the Scottish Nationalists implode, the only (highly unlikely) hope for a good ending to the Brexit debacle would be for the centre and left of the parliamentary Tories to co-operate with the centre and right of the parliamentary Labour Party in the manner they came together in the national interest in 1940.

Was it on the syllabus or was it just some random question? If it was the latter then it seems a bit harsh. In saying that, learning about Brexit and other social and political affairs would be much more beneficial to students than memorising poxy soliloquies from Shakespeare.

@Dj: Questions like this aren’t about the actual topic or even what you say. At this level in language studies it’s common to present a topic like this and ask the student to compare and contrast the topic. It’s not about their actual opinion but about how they can phrase and talk about it in the language.

It’s common for students to be required to be up to date with social and cultural events relating to the language they study, as well as current events. I taught English up to Junior Cert in Sweden, and it’s on the curriculum.
Up to sixth class, kids are required to have at least a basic knowledge of what life is like in the main English-speaking countries.

Interesting and well written article. The UK and Ireland are both victims of the Common Fisheries Policy. When the UK exits, Ireland’s contribution to the EU budget will increase significantly but we dont even include the value of the fish taken for free in our calculation of our contribution. That is madness.
Incidentally, there is no “neighbouring agreement” between NI and Ireland that allows fishing inside the 0-6 mile zone. If you check with the Sea Fisheries Protection Authority (SFPA) they will confirm this. Moreover, Northern Ireland is not a separate country and is not an entity that could ever contract with Ireland under the London Fisheries Convention. This was tested and confirmed by the Supreme Court recently in a case taken by Irish fishermen when Dutch owned mussel farms in Northern Ireland were “somehow” given fishing rights in Ireland for mussels.
The UK and Ireland do allow reciprocal fishing in each other’s 6-12 mile zones based on limited historical areas and species at the time of the Fisheries Convention. Needless to say Ireland got very limited access to the UK …..

I don’t believe that the British have changed very much.
The statement that “A majority of the English public see themselves as something separate, something apart from their European neighbours” hits the nail on the head but that has always, rightly or wrongly, been the case. We have always, rightly or wrongly, seen ourselves as semi-detached from European civilisation. This isn’t about being anti-Irish or anti-Polish or whatever. It isn’t about failing to see the common humanity in a person from Bratislava. It just that an attempt to put our identity into a box which includes Ireland but not Canada, or Austria but not Australia or Spain but not Singapore doesn’t fit with our conception of ourselves. There are obviously some countries with which Brits have more in common than others, and Ireland would be near the top of the list for many people, but you wouldn’t find that the list is full of EU countries at the top and everyone else at the bottom.
It is not the Brits who have changed so much as the EU. We were happy when it was a trading area, but its political ambitions have grown and it is dawning on the Brits that the ultimate plan of some at least (and let’s be honest, the Germans especially) is the creation of a single federal state. We blame the EU for having deceived us about that, even when most of the deception was practiced on ourselves.
Sometimes leavers are criticised for wanting a return to the British Empire, but I think that that misses the point. Whatever British people think about the rights and wrongs of Empire, there is a general feeling of warmth towards ex-colonies and an acknowledgment that independence from Britain, although perhaps not easy, was absolutely the right thing to have happened. We see Ireland, India Canada and Nigeria prospering outside of an Empire, decide that leaving an empire and reclaiming sovereignty is a good thing in principle and we decide we want a bit of that too for ourselves. Trouble is that we are not in an Empire, so we see the EU (not completely without justification – think about the symbolism of signing the Treaty of Rome on the Capitoline Hill) as an emerging empire and kick against that.
@Tim: An ex-empire criticising an emerging empire, thats a bit rich. World trade is all about empires whether it is companies or countries.

@Chris Kirk: By your logic it would be “a bit rich” for Germans to criticise emerging fascism because they (or rather their grand parents) once lived in a fascist state. But I bet you would rightly give the Germans credit for confronting their past and being particularly vigilant about the future even if it occasionally makes their nationalism antenna over sensitive.
The point is that the Brits did empire, we acknowledge that it was wrong and are glad it is now over. That past makes us rather reluctant to be involved in anything that looks even a little bit imperial again. Maybe we are oversensitive, but the British Empire was not wrong because it was British, it was wrong because it was an Empire.

The thing about being Irish or Irish diaspora in England is the fact that the English don’t think of the Irish as “foreign”. In fact, when it comes down to it probably every three in ten has some sort of Irish heritage. In some areas that rises significantly. As many second, third and ,fourth generation offspring have integrated they may appear on the outside to be ” English” or whatnot but they still have even tiny amounts of loyalty to “the hone country”. Also, they haven’t been subject to the rampant propaganda of the early 20th century which prevailed in Irish society after independence right up to the 80′s (note, I am by no means saying independence is a bad thing or that it wasn’t right in Ireland, it simply wasn’t a big thing in GB outside the local community or holidays home).
Having grown up in England during the height of the troubles I, nor my family or friends who were diaspora ever experienced issues for our nationality (that I’m aware of). In fact, we were welcomed into society. Yes there were the paddy jokes and whatnot but back in the day anyone ” different” was fair game before we achieved the upper echelons of snowflake society. In fact, the only thing our family “experienced” in a bad way was regularly being pulled over by the police…that could have been because of the dodgy hand painted Cortina (it was a thing in the early 80s for rusty cars) or it could have been because of my dads strong Donegal accent (perceived as nordie)..hard to prove though! Ultinately, life was pretty ‘normal’ and no different to here.
It’ll be interesting to see how Brexit affects the relationship between Ireland and England\GB, it truly would be a shame if it impacts our ability to be good neighbours, good friends (see what I did there?). I’m pro European and without going into too much detail I would hate to see barriers between these islands…the only issue any of us have in any area of these islands is the the nordie politicians on both sides insistent on hate.
@Alan Walter Gallagher: Older generations have always looked upon the Irish as foreigners and many still do, especially in southern England.

@Chris Kirk: well, I grew up in Bristol, southern England so I would doubt that very much indeed. This reminds me, when growing up and getting ready for the big summer holiday, we would say “were off to Ireland” and the reaction nearly always was “but wouldn’t you prefer to go abroad?”. Ultimately, most English don’t know a great deal about Ireland or Irish nationality because its barely mentioned in the education system, unless they have Irish relatives. Also, you have to bear in mind the English are instinctively inward looking when it comes to anywhere else on these islands. They have their own misguided propaganda touts and many think other places on these islands get some better deal or some such.
Overall, the old saying ” An Englishman’s home is his castle” is pretty much spot on, he will view anyone he doesn’t know particularly well with distain and contempt until he knows them better…that’s why high walls/hedges and net curtains are a big thing over there, its a privacy thing. Don’t be taking it personally, people from Timbuktu would have the very same treatment!

I think that it is difficult to disavow the fact that the Leave campaign shamelessly rode the anti-immigration tiger to victory. It was the argument that won them the vote –even Vote Leave’s campaign director Dominic Cummings admits that. That association now inevitably sticks.
Certainly as an EU immigrant working as a clinician in the NHS, hearing for the last two years how there’s just too damn many of us taking British jobs, housing and benefits has left a bad taste in the mouth. So has May’s rhetoric about “citizens of nowhere” and Rudd’s idea of forcing companies to list their foreign employees and Fox’s referring to us as “bargaining cards” in negotiations with the EU.
So yes, my feelings towards this country that I once loved have changed. Like many of my EU immigrant colleagues in the NHS, I now find myself thinking of leaving.

@Robin: When I worked in Holland the Government made a law requiring companies to report the numbers of foreigners working in the that company. My HR Manager told me that it was not mandatory and if I objected I didn’t have to but they were required to ask and present the figures to Govt. I had no objection and did complete the form. The purpose of the registration was to establish to what degree immigrants were filtering into the workplace and into higher level office jobs. In other words it was a way of establishing the extent of integration. There was a concern since certain areas in Rotterdam, Amsterdam and some other large cities had slums with large numbers of unemployed immigrants and the Govt wanted to establish how good or bad the situation was, and establish employment activation measures, language training etc. in order to improve integration.

@gregory: That is a valid comment (especially as I’m Dutch) but I feel the context here was different: Rudd was talking about levying a financial penalty for every foreign worker employed.
My distaste and concern is mainly towards the government’s behaviour rather than that of the British people, who I think really don’t realise how personal the anti-immigrant narrative that the Leave campaign established around Brexit has felt to us. I have not noticed a difference in the behaviour of British people towards me –although I am arguably so integrated most people probably don’t register I am foreign, and of course our patients don’t care one way or the other. But it is like something was said that has left an embarrassing silence, and now cannot be taken back.

Brexit is happening whether we like it or not. Let’s make it work positively for everyone, on all sides. Then apply what we learn with our UK cousins to the changing relationship with Russia – before it”s too late!
Russia’s move on its former Eastern European countries is as inevitable as Putin’s move on Crimea and Germany”s move on Poland.

The British showed courage and a truckload of self-confidence by voting for Brexit, after the EU bureaucracy had rebuffed former UK prime minister David Cameron’s very reasonable proposals for reform of the European Union (reforms which would have benefitted all EU countries, including Ireland especially).
Now the British Government has been bitterly rebuffed, once again, by Brussels at a critical time when flexibility would have been a more prudent course by Brussels, given the zero room for manoeuvre that Theresa May has in the House of Commons.
The only course left for the UK in the aftermath of yesterday’s EU summit is to once more be self-confident, and boldly leave the EU on March 29th ready to trade on WTO terms. When that happens, the EU will come hurtling up the Channel Tunnel willing to settle for any deal.
The UK being prepared to trade with the EU according to WTO rules does not constitute a “no-deal” or “crash” Brexit (these are emotive terms contrived by the media and by the opponents of Brexit), of which there is no such thing. WTO rules are designed to facilitate orderly and smooth trade and, hence, Brexit on WTO terms would be an orderly Brexit.
After March 29th, if trade between Britain and the EU is based on World Trade Organisation rules, the EU will come looking for a favourable trade deal with the UK because continental European countries (and Ireland) export a lot more to the UK than the UK exports to other EU countries. The EU will also desperately want some more (as a final settlement) of what the UK currently contributes in membership fees. For these two reasons (the UK’s trade imbalance with Europe and the mountains of cash that the UK can give as a kiss-off settlement), Britain has the upper-hand with Brussels if the UK waits until March 30th to sign a deal and shows that it is prepared to do business with the EU on WTO terms.

This note provides some key statistics on the UK’s trade with Ireland. They are taken from
the Office for National Statistics Pink Book 2017 (see tables in Chapter 9) and the HMRC
database UK Trade Info.
• In 2016, UK exports to Ireland were worth £26.7 billion; imports from Ireland were
£20.8 billion, resulting in a trade surplus of £5.9 billion with Ireland.
• The UK had a surplus with Ireland in both goods and services.
• Ireland accounted for 4.9% of UK exports and 3.5% of all UK imports.
• Ireland was the UK’s 5th largest export market and the 9th largest source of imports.
(Source: House Of Commons Briefing Paper 8th Dec 2017)

Scenario: A number of supermarket chains operating here in the Republic sell produce marked “produced in Ireland” and have the tricolour as part of the logo, however when you look at a number of these products (mainly dairy) they have a EU (NI) vet stamp showing they were processed there.
Now after 30 March 2019 if NI is not part of the common trade area with EU regulation in place, then EU regulations may not apply. If the EU regulations do not apply, then the NI products marked as “Produce of Ireland” cannot be marked as such, as to do so would suggest they were made under the EU regulatory regime.

Many people here seem confused. The UK is leaving the EU, not the other way around. Art.50 specifically states that if a country leaves the EU, all treaties will cease to exist. The EU must take into account the whatever agreement they come up with will directly impact any future agreements with other countries as well as current agreements. The EU have standard existing minimum trade requirements many of which the UK are trying to renegotiate, having your cake and eating it springs mind.

@Chris Mansfield:
I believe there’s an agenda in not defining the technology. Lots of large companies already maintain traceability systems to ensure there’s no corruption in their supply chain. For example, pharmaceutical companies have origin traceability which can be used to demonstrate fake prescription drugs sold online etc.
Similarly, large food processors need to monitor and control the contents and the environments in transport vehicles, so they have trusted systems for verifying origins.
Now, here’s the rub. Any technological solution that could cover the next 8-10 years would likely amount to a standards certification and inspection regime being applied to a tweaked version of what certain corporations already do. The technological solution won’t be available to small to medium sized importers, other than where individual registrations can be traced (such as bovine livestock, which was widely fixed due to BSE some time ago).
So a technology solution can be found quickly for the biggest companies, many of which will have the legal and compliance departments to get up to speed rapidly during a transition period. For others, the cost of electronic compliance will be too high.
In the medium to long term, a combination of physical and virtual seals, combined with traceability on a trusted public transaction ledger (e.g. a Blockchain solution) can probably work. A lot of cross-border trade will likely end up going down this road, and the EU and China are already investing in this to weed out counterfeit products and provide accurate food origin traceability in both directions e.g. for beef going to China.

@The Bob: Really its the Spanish Conquistadors, just thought it looked an nice place, looking out from their port in Argentina. But the UK had a flag on it.

@The Bob: The Islands had an Argentinian colony on the Malvinas from 1826-1833, until the British annexed the Islands by force, which is illegal under international law. Now in a but more detail…
Argentina formally claimed the Malvinas in 1820 (after ceding from Sapin, who where the previous de facto owners). By 1826, a year after the British officially recognised Argentine independence, Argentina had a military garrison and colony on the Malvinas promoted by Argentinian businessman Luis Vernet.
However, on the 2nd January 1833 the British annexed the Malvinas; a Captain John Onslow arrived forced Vernet to lower the Argentinian flag, they did not resist due to superior firepower of the British. The British then kicked the garrison off the Island but they allowed Argentinian settlers to stay.
The British claim the Islands because they say they discovered and landed on the Islands first in 1690, but the Island were later claimed by Spain. The British built a fort on the Island 1766, Port Egmont, however, there was no civilian colony established and the British did not defend the sovereignty of the Islands. In fact, the French had established a colony on the Island in 1764, before the British set up their fort, called Port Saint Louis it peaked with a population of 250. The French turned their colony over to Spain in 1766 (renamed port Puerto Soledad) and when the Spanish found out about Port Egmont in 1770 they sent ships to tell the British to feck off, which they did. Spain took control of the Islands.
The British also claim the Argentinians never made a fuss about annexation till 1941. On the other hand, the Argentinians claim they made an official complaint to the British each year from the time of annexation and the annexation was debated in the Argentinian parliament for many years after. Also, US recognised the Malvinas were Argentinian in an 1839 court case (Williams v. Suffolk Insurance Company), over an incident where Vernet had impounded a US whaling ship, the US court recognised that the Islands were indeed Argentinian.

Although it is often argued that the British Empire simply exploited other countries around the world to make itself rich, statistics show this to not be true. Seven of the world’s 10 richest countries—Qatar, Singapore, Kuwait, Brunei, UAE, Hong Kong, and the USA—were once either British colonies or British protectorates.Six of the those countries are in Asia, which also goes to show that the British Empire did not only benefit its North American colonies. During my time in Ireland we grew all our own potatoes and vegetables such as carrots, parsnips , onions and shallots and meats such as beef, pork , chicken, turkeys ducks and geese and fruit such as apples , pears and an array of jam making garden fruit such as strawberries, gooseberries, black and red currants and rhubarb , plumbs and damsons. We grew our own oats and wheat and wheat and ground it for porridge and flour

One remarkable fact that came to my attention in looking into this is the percentage of trucks arriving from outside the EU that Irish Customs currently inspect is 1%, the lowest in Europe. The EU appears quite content for them to do that and doesn’t see that as a systemic threat to the integrity of the single market.
The UK has an inspection rate which is almost, but not quite as low, although the container port in Bristol says that it has only opened 2 containers in the last decade.
The fact is that modern borders don’t typically require a huge amount of inspection of goods.
A UK-Ireland border could potentially be more lightly policed than Ireland’s current border with non-EU countries because:
1, CTA means that people smuggling is not an issue
2, contraband like drugs/guns etc are illegal on both sides of the border,
3, the UK is likely to stay in an all-Ireland animal healthy agreements meaning that veterinary inspections would not normally be needed (unless of course there is something like a foot and mouth outbreak, but when that happens you get movement restrictions and inspections even within a country),
4, a comprehensive FTA would eliminate tariff differentials and therefore an incentive to smuggle many goods.
It doesn’t mean that the post brexit border is not a massive issue and a huge headache that Ireland didn’t ask for and doesn’t want, but it does help to put the size of the problem into perspective. Both NI and Ireland are small places where most trade is local and both places are on an island with a limited number of freight ports out to the wider world.

@Tim: Excellent points.
People forget that there has been free movement between these islands since the 1920s, well before the EU was ever dreamt up.
Of course there was a physical barrier during the troubles, but that was a security, not an economic/trade issue.

English nationalism will eventually split up the UK & the Irish Border debacle is simply the tip of the iceberg. For me some values underpinning Brexit are reasonable. For example, the EC has gone too far in impinging on the sovereignty of its member countries by enacting legislation away outside of its original objective of a common market with the EC acting as a comprehensive Federal Government.
We now have a significant shift to the right among younger generations and sovereign
governments’ ability to change domestic legislation as per political parties’ policies is
essentially hogtied.
For example, I wrote to the Minister for Finance expressing concern that I was being denied Irish Car Insurance simply because I had an Australian Driving Licence while
recent immigrants from East Europe automatically qualified for car insurance was unfair and inequitable even though I was born in Ireland and I now live 3 months a year in Killarney and that I have retained my Irish citizenship for 53 years.
Almost a year later I received a convoluted letter explaining that the relevant Minister could do nothing because the Republic was bound by EC regulations.I simply can’t get an Irish driving licence within 3 months and then when I return to Australia I am required
to change my licence back to an Australian driving licence before I can drive in Australia.
This puts me in a “catch22″ pucker.
The EC (EEC-Common Market) should have stuck with its original plan of being a common trade zone and not a common Government Zone. Objections by populist nationalists throughout the EC now threatens the entire EC/EZ and Brussels will simply have to repeal its raft of laws that do not directly relate to a free trade/free customs zone;
otherwise Brexit will likely lead the way to the EC’s demise.
The original intent of the Common Market was to protect Europe from another WW and free trade was the vehicle. The morphed EC now seeks to be a defacto Federal Government ultimately relegating national governments to Co Council status.
IMO there will be another Brexit Referendum with the option to either accept a hard Brexit or to remain in the EC but by then the Uk will have done considerable economic damage to itself and permanently fractured the UK .
Economic Nationalism seems to be the tool of the “deplorable” who have been left behind by globalisation and 21st GIG Capitalism.

Pretty certain that the B.A. Is not geared to re-man a border either, nor is the UK economy in a position to finance rebuilding it from scratch.
Having had some experience of cross border trade when it was a hard border, when goods traffic was mainly channelled through bonded premises, any & all VAT registered traders can pre apply for import/ export quota licences, settle actual invoiced goods by monthly accounting, & make auditors responsible for verification. The costs of doing this state work could be allowed by fixed credits.
The problem would centre on free movement of people, on unregistered goods movement, including smuggling, as at present, & it would be crazy for either the EU or UK to attempt to rebuild & re- enforce a hard border to deal with it. Hugely expensive,&unworkable

It is also factually correct that the amendments are not to the EU liking, because they ensure the UK will not collect EU tariffs unless the EU collects UK ones and that will be largely based on the Irish border.

The “backstop” is really gone… it went when the UK government announced that it would not be a permanent arrangement anyway. Now the “no border” is really gone too if the UK leaves the Customs Union and drops EU regulations and makes trades deals with the USA. The only real question, based upon the current UK position, is how hard the border will have to be as the UK has said “no border” in the Irish Sea.
Disregarding the UK and Ireland common travel zone (no passport control) the question I pose is how the EU can protect itself from imports of Chicken from the US as it is currently banned as they use chlorine in the production process. Post Brexit the UK could allow this to be imported and what is to stop a consignment from the US arriving in Belfast and being driven to Dublin and on to other EU countries. There are actually two options…. one being customs control on importations from NI (and those being the same as importations for the US or any other non EU country) or there being a customs control on the export of goods from Ireland to the rest of the EU.
Unthinkable as it sounds, there could be checks on our exports to the rest of the EU to ensure that goods are EU compliant. It a customs check going to another EU country is not an option the we have to have a border with proper border controls. The irony of it is that the UK need not implement a hard border on goods entering NI from the rest of the EU via a land route but the EU will insist on border controls on imports into the EU, so when the UK government say “no hard border” they can only talk about the UK side of the border, the EU will dictate the Irish side of the border.
This is actually not a time for political bashing, this is the most important thing to face the country in 50 years at least and everyone should stop wasting brain power knocking others and work on understanding the problems and getting a position that suits Ireland best.
My personal opinion is that we need to stick with the EU, Stirling is in turmoil, the UK industry and financial services are in a panic, major firms has plans to move some operations from the UK, Brexit will almost bankrupt the UK and lead to a reduced standard of living. @Moorooka Mick:
Example of EU legislative bullying:
A year ago I wrote to the Irish relevant minister expressing concern that I was being denied Irish car insurance for my Irish car because I have an
Australian driving licence (15 Irish based car insurers refused to offer me a quote)
I live in Ireland 3 months a year. I am not allowed to have both Aussie & Irish driving licences simultaneously. It takes 4 months in Ireland to swap my Aussie licence for an Irish one and also 4 months to swap my Irish licence for an Aussie one when I return to Aus . I am and have been an Irish citizen all my life.
Following 12 months of toing and froing between ministers, I was finally informed that the Republic is bound by the EU 2009 Motor Insurance Directive and as such the State powerless to assist me in obtaining Irish Car Insurance.
The absurd thing is:
The Gardai recognise my Australian Driving Licence with its international
Endorsement
-I can rent a car in Ireland even for a prolonged period with my Australian Driving Licence without impediment or penalty
-I have driven all my life on the left hand side of the road
-I haven’t had an insurance claim for over 30 years
-my comprehensive car insurance policy in Aus is less than $200 AUD
for a car similar to my Irish one.
I own a house in Ireland and pay my taxes
-Recent arrivals who arrive from East Europe who have never previously
driven on the left hand side , can’t speak English (let alone Gaelge) can
insure their car in Ireland right away.
What are we?
So in my case, EU law (actually a directive) prevents me from getting Irish car insurance and , consequently, the right to drive my own car even though I am well qualified and fit to do so.
No wonder many in the UK favour Brexit because of the EU’s unnecessary and intrusive laws, rules, regulations and directives which
deprive local citizens of their perceived rights.
Before 2009 I had no problem insuring my Irish car.

If I may make an observation on Irish unification from across the Irish Sea (England) it is that it is instructive to listen to the voices of NI unionism and to their arguments against unification. I have noticed that these have changed. The old reasons to be British rather than Irish have faded. These included:
1, Ireland is poor (not any more)
2, Ireland is “backwards” (no longer true if it ever was)
3, Ireland is “priest ridden” (much less so)
4, Ireland was not on the right side in WWII (fading into irrelevance as time passes).
Unionists still (by definition) have reasons to prefer NI being British rather than Irish, but they are much more pragmatic concerns like loosing access to the UK NHS. Crucially many of the concerns of Unionists are now things that in the event of reunification Dublin could, if they were smart, at least partly address. Whilst there are still “hard core unionists”, there are many in NI who have a unionist preference but could live with NI switching from being a somewhat self governing part of the UK with some Irish features to being a somewhat self governing part of Ireland with some British features. I predict that that switch will happen in my life time and so long as it is done smartly, sensitively and cooperatively, I don’t think many in GB would object.
Timing is everything, but I think unification is inevitable in my lifetime. The Irish Government is probably wise to

Examples… “a Statement containing a draft Council Decision on specific provisions relating to the effective management of the banking union and of the consequences of further integration of the euro area which will be adopted on the day the Decision referred to in point (a) takes effect (Annex 2); ”
” to agree arrangements for matters including the role of national Parliaments in the Union, as well as the effective management of the banking union and of the consequences of further integration of the euro area, ”
” Recalling that the process towards the establishment of the banking union and a more integrated governance of the euro area is open to Member States that do not have the euro as their currency, ”
“Council Decision on specific provisions relating to the effective management of the banking union and of the consequences of further integration of the euro area. ”
“2. Union law on the banking union conferring upon the European Central Bank, the Single Resolution Board or Union bodies exercising similar functions, authority over credit institutions is applicable only to credit institutions located in Member States whose currency is the euro or in Member States that have concluded with the European Central Bank a close cooperation agreement on prudential supervision, in accordance with relevant EU rules and subject to the requirements of group and consolidated supervision and resolution.
The single rulebook is to be applied by all credit institutions and other financial institutions in order to ensure the level-playing field within the internal market. Substantive Union law to be applied by the European Central Bank in the exercise of its functions of single supervisor, or by the Single Resolution Board or Union bodies exercising similar functions, including the single rulebook as regards prudential requirements for credit institutions or other legislative measures to be adopted for the purpose of safeguarding financial stability, may need to be conceived in a more uniform manner than corresponding rules to be applied by national authorities of Member States that do not take part in the banking union. To this end, specific provisions within the single rulebook and other relevant instruments may be necessary, while preserving the level-playing field and contributing to financial stability.”
“3. Emergency and crisis measures designed to safeguard the financial stability of the euro area will not entail budgetary responsibility for Member States whose currency is not the euro, or, as the case may be, for those not participating in the banking union. ”

This article described an internal no-confidence vote, which after 48 letters to a Tory committee would trigger the Tory party to choose a new Tory leader. But there is also a parliamentary no-confidence vote. This can be brought by the opposition at any time.
By now it can be assumed that DUP would vote against May, as would the 6 ministers that have already quit for Brexit reasons, plus all the opposition parties. Even without further internal dissent, the government is basically guaranteed to lose such a vote; subsequently fail to form a new government within 14 days; and trigger a General Election.
The only question is what is the opposition’s strategy for timing a no-confidence vote. Better to let the Tories and coalition tear themselves apart, rather than risk the electorate blaming opposition parties.

“May’s predecessor, David Cameron, called the 2016 Brexit referendum as a means of satiating his party’s Eurosceptic wing, while strengthening the UK’s bargaining position with other EU powers, Germany above all. Faced with the disastrous implication of having lost—largely as a result of a protest vote expressing widespread social and political alienation—the ruling elite was thrust into bitter factional conflict over how best to defend Britain’s global interests.
The pro-Brexit factions pinned their hopes on using the election of Donald Trump to piggy-back on US demands for unrestricted access to European markets combined with the right to negotiate independent trade deals internationally. May sought the same end goal but was brought face to face with the reality of Britain’s weak position and the full implications of the growing antagonisms between the US and Europe.
Rather than folding under US pressure, Germany and France have taken a hard line against the UK to preserve the unity of the EU while seeking to strengthen their hand against Washington. The week leading up to the Brexit text announcement was dominated by official commemorations of the centenary of the end of World War I, leading up to the meeting in Paris of 70 world leaders. Such is May’s isolation that she could not contemplate attending and stayed to mark the occasion in London. More significant still, hostile relations erupted between the US, France and Germany over President Emmanuel Macron’s declaration that Europe needed its own army—not only to combat the threat from Russia and China—but in recognition that the US was no longer a reliable ally.”
